div.p: 1. Perhaps the most current general word for peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community is yí dí 夷狄, but sometimes the term refers specifically to the eastern and the northern barbarians.
2. Jiǔ yí 九夷 is another term referring generically to the peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community, but more specifically to those of the East.
3. Sì dí 四狄 is a general term for the various types of peoples that were not taken to belong the Huáxiá 華夏 community, but more specifically to those of the north. Sometimes the term wǔ yí 五夷 is used.
4. Róngdí 戎狄 is another term referring generically to the peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community, but also more specifically to the western and northern barbarians.
5. Mán yí 蠻夷 is another term referring generically to the peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community.
One standard classification of non-Chinese peoples is this:
6. Yí 夷 refers to the barbarians of the east, but the term came to be used for barbarians generally. 東方為九夷，
7. Mán 蠻 refers specifically to the barbarians of the south. 南方為八蠻，
8. Róng 戎 refers specifically to the barbarians of the west. 西方為六戎，
9. Dí 狄 refers specifically to the barbarians of the north. 北方為五狄。
In addition there is a rich vocabulary specifying various non-Chinese ethnic groups.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: Studie zu der Bezeichung barbaros Soziale Typenbegriffe
L'intelligence de la China. Le social et le mental
中華古代文化辭典 Zhonghua gudai wenhua cidian
New Dictiornary of the History of Ideas, 6 vols.

sense.def: dominant people in Mongolia in the Han period

entry.def: Yí 夷 was originally a name of eastern barbarians, later it came to be used as a general term for barbarians.

sense.def: barbarian, of barbarian character, different form what is current in the central areas
a non-Chinese people in Zhou times; eastern barbarian; general: barbarians
be barbarian in nature; belong to the Yi barbarians
Ér Qiāng 婼 羌 people in northern Tibet in the Han period.

entry.def: Dòng is a general term for the southwestern barbarians living in the mountain areas.

sense.def: P: southern non-Chinese people (now written 侗)

entry.def: Bā 巴 is a name of an ancient ethnic group and polity in the area of modern Chongqing. According to the historical texts, the leader of Bā was enfeooffed by the king Wu of Zhōu (>Zhōu Wǔ wáng 周武王) when this had defeated the >Shāng 商. When >Qín 秦 conquered this area, it established there the commandery of Bā 巴君.
Róng 戎 refers to western barbarians.

sense.def: in the manner of the Rong barbarians of the West
Róng barbarian; note that all enemies of the Zhōu were currently described as Róng.
be barbarian, belong to the Ro2ng Barbarians

entry.def: Dī 氐 originally belonged to the western Róng 戎. They were (together with Qiáng 羌) settled in the area of modern Gansu, Qinghai, western part of Sichuan, and northern part of Yunnan.

sense.def: a western people in the Han period.

entry.def: Dí 狄 refers to northern barbarians.

sense.def: 獯 鬻 name of a northern people in prehistoric times. Also 熏 粥, hun1yù 葷 粥, etc.

entry.def: Qiáng 羌 (or western Qiáng, Xī Qiáng 西羌) lived in the area of modern Gansu, Qinghai, western Sichuan, and northern Yunnan). They lived in a nomadic way of life. Their tribes were originally dominated by Xiōngnǔ 匈奴, but thereafter they came under the Hàn 漢 rule.
Hú 胡 in Zhanguo period referred to the barbarians living to the north of the states of Qín 秦, Zhaò 趙 and Yàn 燕, which later became to be known as Xiōngnǔ 匈奴.

sense.def: in the style of a barbarian 胡服 "dress up as a barbarian"

entry.def: Mán 蠻 is a general term for southern barbarians.

sense.def: northeastern people in the Zhou dynasty
used to refer to a Northern barbarian tribe correctly referred to as 貊, often mentioned together with the eastern Yí 夷
P: xiānlián 先 零 branch of the Qiang1 people in the Han dynasty
a northeastern people; xíxí 霫 霫 rainy

entry.def: Jiǔ yí 九夷 is another term referring generically to the peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community, but more specifically to those of the East.

sense.def: the barbarians [NOT: the nine kinds vis-a-vis other kinds of barbarians!]

the Xiōngnú or Huns (Or were they the Huns? Apart from the sinological literature see Otto J. Mänchen-Helfen (ed. Max Knight): The World of the Huns: Studies in Their History and Culture (Berkeley, University of California Press, 1973) )

entry.def: Sì dí 四狄 is a general term for the various types of peoples that were not taken to belong the Huáxiá 華夏 community, but more specifically to those of the north. Sometimes the term wǔ yí 五夷 is used.

sense.def: barbarians which surround the whole of China in all directions

entry.def: Yí and Dí barbarians> by metonymy: barbarians in general. Perhaps the most current general word for peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community is yí dí 夷狄.
Róngdí 戎狄 is another term referring generically to the peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community, but also more specifically to the western and northern barbarians.

sense.def: the Yǒuróng semi-sinicised state of Shandong [MOVE TO STATES]
the Yǒu Mín barbarian tribe native to Shāndōng
northern barbarian tribe, also known as 獫狁

entry.def: Xiǎnyǔn 玁狁 was a powerful group of barbarians located somewhere in the area to the north of a royal domain in the Western Zhōu period. In the reign of king Xuān of Zhōu 周宣王 (828-782 B.C.), they attacked the central area of the Zhōu state in Shǎnxī (in 816 B.C., according to Shaughnessy), but were eventually defeated. The event is described in inscriptions on bronze vessels, and also in several poems in SHIJING. [JM]

sense.def: Western Barbarians (a general term referring to a group of North-Western minority peoples, and the term can only be used to refer to the group as a whole, not in this sense to an individual who belongs to that group)
barbarian Huns, better known as 薰粥

entry.def: Mán yí 蠻夷 is another term referring generically to the peoples who were taken not to belong to the Huáxiá 華夏 community, and more specifically to the barbarians of the south and east.

sense.def: general barbarians of all description (not just the Man and the Yi
